newsitem.title: USA: Petsmart stock slumps after earnings warning.
newsitem.headline: Petsmart stock slumps after earnings warning.

text.p: Petsmart Inc. shares tumbled to a 12-month low Thursday, a day after the company warned of disappointing quarterly earnings, sparking concerns about the pet products retailer's operations.
The stock slid as low as $9.19, before ending down 81 cents at $10.81 on Nasdaq. It was the second the most heavily traded issue, with almost 18.3 million shares changing hands.

The retailer said late Wednesday it expected to report earnings of about 5 cents a share for the first quarter ended May 4, or about half of the Wall Street consensus estimate according to First Call, which tracks analysts' estimates.
Petsmart lost $7.6 million, or 6 cents a share, on sales of $457.4 million in the fourth quarter.

Analysts said inventory problems accounted for about two-thirds of the earnings shortfall. Inaccurate data was fed into a computerized inventory system, leaving the Phoenix-based company without many essential items, they said.
"They were overstocked at the end of the fourth quarter and they were understocked by the end of the first quarter," said Joan Bogucki, an analyst at Needham & Co.

"They had shortfalls in inventories due to some executional screw-ups," said Bill Armstrong of Fahnestock & Co. "People are wondering if management really has their thumb on the execution side of the business."

Petsmart stock has fared poorly in recent months. On March 22 Petsmart traded as high as $22 before falling to $16.8125 by April 30. Last Friday, Petsmart's investment bank Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette downgraded the stock and removed it from its recommended list, sending it skidding $3.8125 to $12.125.
"We made some misguided decisions in hindsight," said Susan Schnabel, Petsmart's chief financial officer who recently joined the firm from DLJ.
She said in an interview that management had been distracted from the day-to-day running of the company by recent acquisitions and needs to focus on basics.
"It certainly is being addressed and aggressively addressed," Schnabel said.
Chris Vroom, an analyst at Alex Brown said the company's complex accounting procedures accentuated its problems, leading to higher expenses when inventories were low.

"They made a very serious mistake on their buying system and they were not keeping appropriate control over that system," he said. "It has precipitated a credibility problem with investors and that is likely to persist probably until the third quarter."

Analysts blamed the rest of the earnings shortfall to a consumer shift away from flea and tick collars, powders and sprays in favour of pills and other new treatments which are only available through veterinarians.
Sales of flea and tick items can account for as much as 10 percent of sales during the spring months, analysts said.
